story.text: NEW YORK Jan 2 Fitch Ratings on Tuesday upgraded defense contractor Raytheon Co.'s debt rating by one notch, citing the company's plan to sell its Raytheon Aircraft business for $3.3 billion and use some of the proceeds to retire debt. Raytheon (RTN.N), the No. 5 Pentagon contractor, said last month it was selling Raytheon Aircraft to a unit of investment bank Goldman Sachs (GS.N) and Canadian buyout firm Onex Partners (OCX.TO). The aircraft unit, which makes business jets and military training planes, has been lagging competitors and falling behind Raytheon's more profitable defense operations. For details, see [ID:nN21469961]. Raytheon's debt will decline by more than 40 percent as a result of early retirement of debt and scheduled debt maturities in 2007, Fitch estimated. The rating upgrade also reflects solid performance in Raytheon's government and defense businesses and strong cash generation in 2006, Fitch said. Fitch raised Raytheon's rating to "BBB-plus," the third-lowest investment grade, from "BBB." The outlook is stable, indicating another rating change is not expected over the next one to two years. Raytheon's 4.85 percent notes due in 2011 traded at a spread of 0.58 percentage points more than Treasuries on Tuesday, in from 0.59 percentage point on Dec. 1, their previous reported trade, according to MarketAxess.
story.title: fitch upgrades raytheon ' s debt rating one notch
